This is the first time I have heard of medical gentlemen being unanimous about anything; and, for that reason, I have very grave suspicions about this list.
I urge the Chancellor to consider very carefully indeed the wisdom of including these words in the Schedule. By greatly increasing the cost of a number of drugs his proposal would bring hardship to many people who could ill afford the addition. For example, there are drugs which relieve headaches. [Interruption.] The hon. Member, I know, speaks with feeling on that matter; but there are many people who suffer from headaches. Why should they be unable to relieve headaches because they cannot afford the extra cost of the drug? There are other drugs which have to be taken continuously, such as liquid paraffin and Epsom salts. Drugs of that kind, taken once a month, are not expensive, but, taken every day, they undoubtedly cause considerable expense to the family. Are those drugs included in this list as being of "exceptionally costly character"? If not, why not? I hope that we may have more information about this mysterious list, and that the Chancellor
will consider this Amendment, and accept it.

I am exceedingly anxious that one aspect of this problem of patent and branded medicines should receive consideration. That aspect is likely to be overlooked, unless it is taken into consideration apart from the general problem of medicines. This is a matter with peculiar a history. In the first place, the Chancellor, when considering the Purchase Tax, laid down a general principle that articles should not be subject to the tax if they were already subject to special and heavy taxation. I do not want to raise the question of the opinions of Members about these proprietary medicines; I want them to consider a very important point of financial principle. The Chancellor indicated that any article or commodity already subject to heavy taxation, would not come under the Purchase Tax. This class or article is already subject to taxation ranging from 25 per cent, to 35 per cent. The lower percentage tax is levied on the cheaper price of medicines. When we impose the Purchase Tax on these cheaper medicines, it will lift a great range of them to the level of the higher-priced medicines, thereby attracting the heavier percentage of Stamp Duty. Therefore the cheaper range of medicines will become subject to a three-tier type of taxation—first the original Stamp Duty, then the Purchase Tax, which lifts them into the higher grade, and the higher Stamp Duty which would follow automatically. I do not feel that on reflection the Committee would wish to see a process of that character introduced. I remember that when the late Chancellor of the Exchequer, in response to the recommendation of a Select Committee, proposed to abolish the Stamp Duty it raised very considerable feeling. I am not in any way anxious to raise that problem to-night, but the Committee will see the fairness of this point. This type of article should not be subject to a double system of taxation.
If the Chancellor of the Exchequer feels that this group of commodities should come under his Purchase Tax and that the revenue he would get by levying the Purchase Tax would yield him a bigger sum on this class of goods, he ought to repeal the original Stamp
Duty. I believe that the revenue from the Purchase Tax would prove to be larger, but I do not know. If, on the other hand, he feels that the original Stamp Duty should be adhered to, I do not think that he ought to impose the Purchase Tax upon that group of goods. The Chancellor of the Exchequer should recognise that very material point and make some concession, either by repealing the original Stamp Duty or withdrawing the Purchase Tax on this class of goods.

In view of the request of the Chairman that all these various medicine matters should be taken in one Debate, I wish to draw the attention of the Committee to the Amendment which stands in my name—in page 44, line 23, column 3, after "liver," to insert: and including all medicines liable to duty chargeable under the Medicines Stamp Act, 1802, the Stamp Act, 1804, and the Medicines Stamp Act, 1812, and any enactment amending those Acts"— to which the hon. Gentleman the Member for East Ham, South (Mr. Barnes) made reference. I am very glad to feel that I have his support, and, in view of what he has said, I will not detain the Committee for more than a very few minutes. I will remind the Committee of the Debate which took place during the Committee stage of the Finance Bill in 1939. Sir John Simon brought to the Committee a proposal that the Medicine Stamp Acts should be repealed. He was acting upon the advice of a Select Committee which had gone thoroughly into the whole question of the anomalous position of those Acts, which are over 100 years old, and have imposed taxation upon certain proprietary medicines in a manner which was judged by the Committee at that time to be extremely unfair. One medicine is taxed and another is not taxed, and no one can explain why the one is taxed or the other is not. There is no distinction and indeed there is no difference between the medicines. Sir John Simon probably made the mistake of coming to the Committee and proposing that these taxes should go by the board without having anything to put in their place. The Committee, generally, felt two things. The first was that medicines,
particularly proprietary brands of medicines, which are heavily advertised and are known to make considerable profits, were a fit subject for taxation and that it was reasonable that they should bear taxation to help the country. The other was that there should be some method of control so that those household remedies in which people have come to believe and which, in fact, are very often recommended by doctors and are of real value, might continue to be sold whereas nostrums and quack remedies which very often are harmful, or at any rate of little use, might be prevented from being sold.
It was generally felt, I think, that there should be taxation and that there should also be some discrimination. Sir John Simon did not bring to the House any proposals to take the place of the legislation he was going to repeal. In those circumstances a very considerable Debate took place and the House of Commons showed itself very unwilling to take Sir John Simon's advice. These Stamp Duties were, therefore, retained and the same anomaly remains. Sir John Simon proposed that between then and his next Budget, that is between 1939 and 1940, he should consult with the interests concerned and try to bring in a proposal which would be fair and on which there would be agreement. No doubt he would have done that if war had not broken out. War did break out, and this small matter had to go by the board. We find ourselves now with the anomalies remaining—some medicines paying Stamp Duty and some not paying it—and the Chancellor of the Exchequer proposes to place a tax on practically all medicines except those on the list which the hon. Member for Swindon (Mr. Wakefield) mentioned.
The effect of this is peculiarly inequitable and whether we, individually, care for proprietary medicines or not, there is a principle involved—a principle of equity and a principle of taxation which I feel the Committee ought not to allow to pass without comment. The tax on patent medicines works in this way. On a shilling bottle or box of medicine there is a duty of 3d. If the retail price of the medicine rises to is. 1d. or is. 2d. the 3d. Stamp Duty rises to 6d. The Chancellor of the Exchequer proposes to put a tax of 16 per cent. on the retail price of 1s., and the cost of the medicine is increased by 2d. That immediately causes this commodity to attract a duty of 6d.—
one of the hundred-year old taxes—instead of 3d. The medicine is, in fact, taxed at 8d., where at present the tax is only 3d. Even fur coats and diamonds and other luxury goods which can be bought only by the very rich are only taxed at the rate of 30 per cent.
It seems wrong to me that through an accident of ancient legislation this particular industry should be taxed as if the goods they were selling were luxuries bought by the few. They are not luxuries bought by the few; they are household commodities bought by the many. A great many people have faith in them, and they do people good. It therefore seems to me that a strong case has been made out for the Chancellor of the Exchequer giving way on the Amendment which is to be moved later. He may ask, "How can I give way on this when I have had to refuse on matters which appear more important?" May I point out to him that the principle here involved does not operate in any of the other cases debated to-day. There is no other case in which a special tax, due to special legislation, is levied on any commodity. I cannot help feeling that injustice is being done to this particular industry and also that an unwarrantable increase will be made in the tax on medicines which are bought by people of limited means. Finally, while probably the Chancellor must reject proposals to exclude medicines as a whole, because such a concession might cost him many millions, this concession will only cost about £100,000. If he grants this Amendment, or some variation of it, he will not lose much revenue. He knows that he ought not to have the revenue, because it is a pure fluke that he is getting it, and he can therefore afford to do what is equitable and just. I ask him to consider this matter should I move my Amendment at a later stage.

I should like to say a few words first about the question of patent medicines and the special tax. I had to take the position as I found it. I have read the Debates which took place when ray predecessor brought the matter forward and proposed to remove the duty, and at that time I think there were no fewer than 300 Members who signed the memorial—it was far worse than the question of the book tax—saying that in no circumstances should we do this.
We are not asking the right hon. Gentleman to remove the Stamp Duty.

I agree. I am explaining my position in the matter. In those circumstances, and for the reasons which have been mentioned by my two hon. Friends, the Chancellor met the wishes of the House of Commons and did not proceed with this proposal. It is in those circumstances that I have to deal with the matter to-night and I felt that at this juncture, with a Budget of this particular character, I could not embark upon a solution of the problem. I came to the conclusion that I had better deal with the situation as I found it and re-impose the tax. It is true, I agree, that there is a considerable anomaly in the matter. I am prepared to give an undertaking to endeavour, between now and the next Finance Bill, to see whether I cannot get the parties together and get some reasonable solution of the matter. I feel that that is the only possible way of tackling it. I could not possibly, at this stage, make an exception and let out a particular class of medicines or drugs. As a matter of fact, at present the Medicine Stamp Duty is chargeable on certain medicines when sold by grocers or general retail stores, but not on those medicines if sold by chemists. If I accepted the Amendment on the Paper, which I could not possibly do, and which the Committee would not desire me to do, the result would be to impose the Purchase Tax on those medicines when sold by a chemist but not when sold by grocers or others. That shows the difficulty of the situation. Therefore, though I admit all that has been said, I feel that we must face the position as it is, but I will make an earnest effort, if I can get the support of both sides, to get a reasonable solution, because the present position is perfectly impossible.
I want to say a word or two about the general position of medicine and drugs and the proposals in the Bill. I again endeavoured to meet the situation and at the same time secure a certain amount of revenue which I thought ought to be contributed from this source. I have set down, in the third column of the Schedule, surgical and medical appliances which are of an exceptionally costly character, and of which some illustrations are given in the Schedule. What we had
in mind was that those medicines which were already very costly ought not to enter into the mind of the medical practitioner when he was giving them to his patient. We have indications in the Schedule of the various kinds of medical and surgical appliances we had in mind, and the Committee will have a full opportunity of seeing this particular list because it will come forward on a particular section of the Bill which allows the Treasury to make the necessary definitions, within the terms of the Section, and will come before the House for approval. Nearly all the matters mentioned by my hon. Friend in his speech will be covered. He asked about persons suffering from secondary anaemia, and I understand from advice I have received that this is connected with the liver and will be free. Various other matters are also set out in the Schedule.
Pernicious anaemia is primary anaemia, not secondary anaemia.

I stand corrected. The advantage is that by the method we have adopted in the Bill we shall be able to add to it from time to time in the light of experience. It is also true that in the other column of the Schedule we are asking the Committee, with these exclusions as specified in the second column, to permit a duty of 16⅔ per cent, upon drugs and medicines, manufactured or prepared. In this I am supported in many quarters of the Committee. When this matter was debated during the Debate on the Medicine Duty a great body of opinion in the House considered it was a proper thing that if you made the exceptions I have referred to, there should be a contribution towards taxation from this source. I am fortified in my observations by the Chief Medical Officer of Health, in his annual report for 1935, in which he almost invited taxation of medicines, even of the sort prescribed by doctors. On page 66 of the report he says: A considerable proportion of the total outlay on drugs prescribed by the medical profession, averaging 3s. per head, could be limited without detriment, indeed with advantage, to the proper treatment of the people. A year later, in his report, he said: In some areas insured persons have acquired a habit of medicine drinking which the practitioners in those areas are reluctant
to control. It has been stated by representative practitioners that a very large proportion of the present medicinal treatment of the population is wholly unnecessary, and if all doctors felt themselves free to order only such medicinal treatment as in their unfettered judgment they considered necessary, the total cost of prescribing would at once fall spectacularly. It is difficult to reconcile ourselves to the wasteful expenditure on drugs and the large sums which otherwise would be available for more effective treatment. I have also read in this connection a speech by an hon. and gallant Member who has passed away during the present crisis and whom we all respected and admired for his speeches on this matter—the late Sir Arnold Wilson. The speech which he made on medicines on 22nd June, 1939, is well worth reading. He reminded the House on that occasion of some observations of his nurse, who said: Remember, child, that doctors think more men have died from drugs than drink."—[OFFICIAL REPORT, 22nd June, 1939; col. 2579, Vol. 348.] That may be perfectly true. I think the proper thing for the Committee to do is to protect those kinds of medicines, drugs and appliances which are necessary, but at the same time I think it is right that a contribution should be made from the general class of medicines. I need not again remind the Committee of the very large exemptions I have made in relation to surgical appliances. In the circumstances, I suggest that we are taking a reasonable course to-night and one that could well be defended.

I am sorry that my first speech on my return to the House should deal with a medical matter, because it is very difficult for a medical man to speak to a lay audience, or to a Committee consisting of lay Members, on medical matters.
It is a matter of condescending to speak.

Just as the Member does when he speak on land values. The speech to which we have just listened was quite unworthy of the Chancellor of the Exchequer. It was ribald, ironical and cynical about a great profession whose services the right hon. Gentleman may need at any time. We have to-night heard some of the most extraordinary statements from all sides of the Committee. We have, for
example, heard the hon. Member for Spen Valley (Mr. Woolley) talking of secondary anaemia when he meant primary anaemia.
I did not mean primary anaemia. I said what I meant—secondary anaemia.
The hon. Member also mentioned the treatment of secondary anaemia by certain organic substances, including liver.
I did not make any reference to the treatment of secondary anaemia by liver.

I apologise if I made a mistake in interpreting the hon. Member, bat I thought he referred to secondary anaemia being treated by certain organic substances, including liver. We also heard the hon. Member for Swindon (Mr. Wakefield) talking about the continuous administration of paraffin. But in medicine we try, unlike the law, to speak a little carefully, with some regard to meticulous accuracy. In medicine you cannot pour, so far as I know, paraffin continuously down anyone's intestinal trap. You may take intermittent doses three times a day or one nightly, but you cannot do it continually. The thing is impossible. I have heard of a river of water, but not of paraffin flowing through the human body. Perhaps those who do not practise every day, and those who do not visit the sick every day, may know better than I do.
This is an unworthy tax. It is a tax on the sick and suffering at a stage when things worthy of taxation are left untouched. To think that the Chancellor is to put a Purchase Tax on things which may relieve suffering, making doctors think twice before ordering certain medicines, is really a scandal to the financial system of the country. What does the Chancellor do to back up his statement? He produces a statement from a medical bureaucrat, sitting in a comfortable office in the Ministry of Health. In medicine no person is so hateful as the medical bureaucrat, the man completely isolated from his patients, the man who remains in an office with a nice salary and a nice pension, and leaves other people to do his work, talking pontifically to those outside, and saying people are taking too much medicine. There are plenty of
people in this country who need more medicine than they are getting at the moment, and I am not quite sure in my own mind whether that does not apply to the Front Bench. There are individuals who are too poor to buy medicines, even patent medicines not prescribed by doctors. You have only to walk through the East End to see crowds of anaemic women whose health would be considerably improved if given, not organic liver extracts, but simply a little chemical treatment, such as iron, arsenic or things of that kind. Arsenic is quite a useful drug. The point I wish to make is that the Chancellor, in trying to defend this tax, gave a quotation from a Ministry of Health official, completely out of touch with the common people. He had not practised medicine for years or seen a patient for years, but sat in his chair and wrote, as medical officers of health frequently do, a lot of complete nonsense, absolutely foreign to medicine. I suggest that in a serious discussion in the House of Commons in taxing suffering the Chancellor should really use a stronger argument than to use a quotation five years out of date to bolster up a case which is as weak as anything presented to this Committee.
This tax is a serious matter for many poor individuals and many institutions which have to cater for the poor. I am associated with one in which the poor patients pay one penny a week in order to get proper treatment from their hospitals which they cannot get anywhere else. This penalisation of the poor from the point of view of the treatment of disease should not be carried out at the present time. It is not a tax deserving of Parliament in a national emergency. Go through the factories to-day and consider the risk the workers are running in industry; go through Government factories, as I have done recently. I could spot one by one patients needing treatment, but no doctor was attached to the premises. All things needed for their treatment are now to be taxed. I suggest that the Chancellor should recast the tax and I appeal to him to do so on behalf of the poor who will have to pay. I do not appeal for the rich, who can always go to the Riviera and elsewhere. [Laughter.] My information is that they are still going to the Riviera, and they are still being allowed to take out money whether they go to the East or to the
West. I am not concerned with the rich who can afford to pay these taxes. I am concerned with the poor and those institutions catering for the poor who will have to pay taxes on these medicines and surgical appliances. If there is one thing in any fiscal system which should be exempt from taxation it is drugs of any kind, whether they are chemical, organic or vaccine.

Column 2 refers to medical and surgical appliances except as specified in the third column. In the third column it says: Medical and surgical appliances and essential drugs, being appliances or drugs of an exceptionally costly character. I should like to ask the Chancellor whether the words in the second column include the syringe which I have to use every day. I have to pay 15s. for a syringe. The needles have been taxed once since I have been in the House. They used to be 4d. and are now 6d. I was told I could have German needles, but I preferred British because they are better. Are these needles and syringes included in the 33⅓ tax?
If they are medical and surgical appliances, as I should think from the hon. Member's description they are, they are exempt.

As it has been decided to discuss all the medicine Amendments together, I desire to draw attention to that in the names of my hon. Friend the Member for Twickenham (Mr. Keeling) and myself to exempt drugs and medicines supplied to registered medical or dental practitioners for use in the discharge of their professional duties and supplied to registered pharmacists or registered medical or dental practitioners for use in dispensing as a component part of medicines prescribed by such practitioners. Unfortunately my hon. Friend is serving his country in another capacity this evening. If he had been present he could have spoken with authority as a member of the Select Committee on the Medicine Stamp Duties which reported in 1937. We have heard an account of the proprietary remedies as affected by these duties, and something of what happened during the Budget Debate of 1939. But
we have not been reminded that the Select Committee recommended the retention of the Stamp Duties. It was felt that the prosperous proprietary medicine industry, with a turnover of £20,000,000, was suitable for taxation in the national interest, and this opinion was endorsed by the House of Commons in the most emphatic manner when the Chancellor of the Exchequer, in 1939, proposed to repeal the duties.
That is all I want to say about the Medicine Duties; but the Select Committee also recommended that medicines dispensed by or on behalf of registered medical practitioners should be exempted from tax, and that is the proposition which I would submit to the Chancellor to-night. The opinion of that Committee was that although the luxury remedies, so popular with those of us who enjoy self-medication, could make a handsome contribution to the revenue, the drugs which were essential to the needs of pharmacists and registered medical practitioners were necessities like food and, like food, should not be subjected to taxation. The arguments in support of that view have been repeated again and again in this Committee, and I inflicted them on the House when I asked for the exemption of drugs and appliances used by hospitals. I do not propose to restate them; but I must emphasise the point that any increase in the cost of drugs and appliances may mean delay in seeking early treatment or at best inflict serious extra expense on a patient at a time when he can least afford it.
I do not want to introduce any controversial matter at this late hour, but while the hon. Member for Swindon (Mr. Wakefield) thought that it was a shocking thing that a person suffering from headache should not be able to buy a cheap remedy I am thinking of cases with headaches as a symptom, in which it may be a matter of life and death for a man to get skilled medical attention without delay. I submit that anything which delays early treatment or places it beyond the means of the patient is bad, and that anything which may be detrimental to the health of the people in these days of stress and strain, is bad. In the opinion of those with most experience of conditions of health among the people, the imposition of the Purchase Tax on drugs and medicine could
not fail to have detrimental effects on the health of the community. I hope that it is not too late to convince the Chancellor in this matter. One can understand other requests for exemption being refused, but, in regard to the proper treatment of diseases and the protection of the people, we ought not, for the sake of a few thousands of pounds, to take risks which are not justified.

I support what was said by my hon. and gallant Friend the Member for Lonsdale (Sir Ian Fraser), and I am very sorry that the Chancellor could not find it in his heart to do something to remedy what his speech showed he thought was an injustice and an anomaly. He gave an undertaking—and we know that half a loaf is better than no bread— that the matter would be gone into before the next Finance Bill; is he prepared to tell the Committee when that is likely to be, and how long the pharmaceutical profession are to exist with this grievance before any remedy is forthcoming? The Committee should realise that the Amendment of the hon. and gallant Member has the support of the Pharmaceutical Society.
I welcomed the Chancellor's promise to consider this matter with a view to putting matters right, but if it is to take a long time, it seems hardly fair to leave matters as they are. I do not want to enter into the controversy between the two medical Gentlemen on either side of the Committee, but when I heard the hon. Member for Rochdale (Dr. Morgan) suggest that what we needed was more medicine and call attention to the Front Bench—although he did not specify which Front Bench—I noticed signs of alarm. I am reminded of the old adage contained in the lines: Better to hunt in fields for health unbought, Than fee the doctor for a nauseous draught. Certain medicines are good for health, but too much self-doctoring by the community is very dangerous. I want to see this anomaly of taxation of patent medicines remedied. Nobody wants them to go untaxed, but the unfair incidence of taxation must be put an end to at the earliest possible moment.

There are one or two points I should like to put to the Chancellor, on which he might make a genuine concession. His generous heart has been moved to sympathy for the blind; he is prepared to exempt altogether gramophone records specially prepared for them. There might be some hope for people who become maimed and afflicted. They should not be compelled to suffer, and then be fined by the State because they have sought some cure. The Chancellor seemed to arrive at the position of Samuel Butler in "Erewhon," where those were penalised who were ill or infirm, while those guilty of normal crime roamed the country free. [An HON. MEMBER: "They were sent to hospital."] Yes, and the others were sent to gaol. They were sent to hospital so that they would be able to roam the country free.
In a previous discussion, the Chancellor suggested it was difficult to divide fabric piece-goods into the more expensive and the cheaper grades. But now at this stage drugs and medicines can be separated; and the costly ones are those which are to go free, and the cheaper ones which the people can afford, will be taxed. Almost every hon. Member will have amongst his personal acquaintances men who went through the last war and were either wounded or gassed so that they are now in receipt of a pension. That pension is the total of their income. They are being hit by the increased cost of living and they are probably the chemists' best customers, because of their desire to get some relief from the wounds of 20 years ago. They have gone through 20 years of suffering, and now when we have another war these people are being singled out to pay special taxation because they are the victims of the last war.
I notice that the Financial Secretary seems to treat it as a joke. It is not nearly such a good joke as the Chancellor of the Exchequer reading from a medical authority, who had a more profound knowledge of human realities. I do not ask the Financial Secretary to take my word for it. If he wants confirmation let him go to a chemist's shop and the chemist will inform him that among his best customers for certain articles, are men who were wounded in the last war. If he does not believe that these people exist—evidently they do not
in official minds, but they do in fact—let him take the victims of this war. In every air-raid when property is demolished there are a number of minor casualties. The least wounded will need a bandage and some iodine. Those simple remedies are included in the tax. If we are caught by splintered glass in an air-raid, let us thank God for it, because it will mean more money for the Exchequer.
Take the case of every workshop, factory and shop. By law, a first-aid outfit must be provided, and for that additional tax will have to be paid. Here is one point where the Chancellor could give way to some extent with the approval of the whole community. We are glad to have the assurance with regard to patent medicines, but I would like the Chancellor when he goes into the matter to bear in mind the fact that the consideration which he himself mentioned bears very heavily on a considerable section of the community. The chemist is now able to make a greater profit. Under this arrangement there will be a difference between the chemist's price for a patent medicine and that of the village grocer. Some of them charge the extra amount, but not all. The whole village community of this country are shut off from chemists' shops. Very few villages in England are of a sufficient size to make it profitable for a chemist to open a business there. Therefore, in almost every village there is a general store where all these patent medicines, for which there is a regular demand, are stocked. The country folk, who for the most part live on agricultural wages, are being told, "If you want them at the lower price, you must wait until you can go into the town." I hope the Chancellor will take into consideration the position of the country folk in relation to these patent medicines.

I disapprove heartily of this tax, but I hope that if the Chancellor makes any concession, he will on no account consider making concessions on the lines suggested by the hon. and gallant Member for Blackburn (Captain Elliston). I can imagine nothing more unwarranted than exempting from taxation medicines recommended by qualified practitioners.
Doctors have had a great deal of knowledge available to them, of which they have made singularly little use. Had they done their work better, much less medicine would have been needed. A very great deal of the suffering in the world is being stamped out by those who come from outside the medical profession. The medical profession is the closest trade union in the world, and I hope that no further unjustifiable advantage will be given to it.
Is it proposed to tax bandages and other first-aid appliances? There is some difficulty in the minds of hon. Members about this.
Bandages are exempt, and I have already announced that I propose to accept the Amendment dealing with surgical appliances.

In view of the assurance which the Chancellor gave us, my hon. Friends and I feel that we would like the Committee to allow us not to move our Amendment. But Sir John Simon gave us exactly the same assurance as my right hon. Friend gave us to-night; then the war came and prevented him from redeeming his promise, while, when the next opportunity came, he was not here to redeem it. We cannot be sure, although we may hope, that the present Chancellor will be here for the next Finance Bill. Can he give any assurance on behalf of the Government that this situation, which he himself says is bad, and which it is commonly known must be dealt with, will be dealt with by the next Budget?

I understood the Chancellor to say that there was some list at the Ministry of Health. Did I correctly understand him to say that there would be some consultation in order to get an agreed list? I do not want to press this Amendment to a Division. If we could get some indication that there would be time to get an agreed list—which request, I think, is more than justified in view of the fact that hon. Members have no knowledge of it at the moment—that would meet the view of my hon. Friends and myself.

As regards the Patent Medicines Tax, I have already stated
that I will try to come to an arrangement on this matter which, I think, will be acceptable to hon. Members. An assurance in this matter by the Chancellor of the Exchequer is obviously given on behalf of the Government of the day.
Are you speaking on behalf of the Government?

Obviously, the proposals of the Government of the day are expressed by the Chancellor of the Exchequer. With regard to the point made by my hon. Friend the Member for Spen Valley (Mr. Woolley), I propose to put down an Amendment on the Report stage dealing with the list, which will be formulated by the Treasury, and which will have to come before the House. The Amendment will provide that notice shall be given in some form or other of the proposals in the list. Obviously, it must be notice that will give the House time to make any reasonable representations.
In view of that assurance, I beg to ask leave to withdraw the Amendment.
Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.
That disposes of all Amendments down to that of the hon. Member for Halifax (Mr Gledhill) in page 133.

I beg to move, in page 44, column 1, to leave out lines 24 and 25, and to insert those lines in column 2.
The object of the Amendment is to transfer typewriters, dictaphones, calculating machines and other office machinery from the higher rate of tax to the lower rate of tax. This principle has already been accepted in the case of account books. Office equipment and machinery are equally necessary, I submit, under modern conditions.
Speak up.

If hon. Members would not talk, they would probably hear me. Statistics of all kinds have to be kept by firms to-day due to the large number of regulations issued by Government Departments who also ask for many returns, all of which entail many hours of hard work and the use of office machinery such as typewriters and
duplicating machines. I understand that the Chancellor of the Exchequer is also expected to make a concession to exempt books on the ground that a tax on books would be a tax on knowledge. If that is so, a tax on office machinery would be a tax on efficiency.
My final point, which I hope will have some influence upon the Chancellor of the Exchequer, is that in his Budget statement he said he needed cash. These, like many other products, are subject to the Limitation of Supplies Order, and their sales are limited by one-third already. If the higher rate of tax is put on the remaining sales, it will drive out of the market the ordinary buyer, and the position will then be that the only remaining buyer of any size will be the Government themselves. Therefore the Chancellor of the Exchequer will find that he has levied a tax which his Department and other Departments are paying for him. Ordinary buyers will be ruled out by the Government more or less taking in their own washing. I submit, therefore, there is a case for either total exemption of these goods or at least their removal from the higher rate of tax, and I appeal to the Chancellor to give consideration to the proposal.

The Amendment which my hon. Friend has moved will have the effect of reducing the charge on typewriters and other office machinery to the reduced rate instead of the basic rate. At the present time I am proposing that typewriters and other office equipment should be taxed at the higher rate, and I commend that proposal because I think it is right. At this particular time—and I think it is gradually taking place—men of a special or a semi-skilled character previously engaged on the manufacture of typewriters can be much better employed. They are the type of men required in many branches of our machine works, and we ought to give every encouragement to that particular type of men to become employed on our special war effort. We must, as best we can, as far as typewriters and things of that kind are concerned, rely upon the typewriters we have already and do the necessary repairs. Such revenue as I can collect in that matter I shall collect. I think I am right in putting this provision in the Schedule.
Amendment negatived.

I beg to move, in page 44, column 1, to leave out lines 35 to 37, and to insert those lines in column 2.
It seems to me undesirable to tax tools of trade. I agree that the tools in this case are not so important as those we have just been discussing, but I understood that the Purchase Tax was to be primarily a tax on luxuries. I cannot think that a tax affecting as it does in this case pencils, pens, fountain pens, ink, drawing pins, and other stationery and office requisites can come under any definition of a tax restricting luxuries. No doubt the Chancellor of the Exchequer will give some reason why his advisers have somewhat strangely included these things, and in order to give him an opportunity of doing so I beg to move.

The position is that I have included in column 1 pens and pencils and other articles of that kind because I suggest they should pay 33⅓ per cent. I did not say that the first column should be confined to luxury articles only. I said it would include other articles which could be done without or postponed. My hon. Friend who has just sat down has suggested that as a certain number of pencils may be used for business purposes they may therefore be considered tools of trade. He would be the first to realise, I think, that a good many pencils are used for other purposes. It would be impossible for a person who sold pencils to know whether they were in fact going to be used for some necessary purpose such as the equipment of my hon. Friend's office, or whether they were going to be used, say, for marking bridge scores. In those circumstances it is impossible to make a distinction, and I do not think there will be any hardship in carrying out the suggestion I have made.

I was interested to hear the explanation of my right hon. Friend, and I know it is no use pressing the Amendment, but, on the other hand, I do not think his explanation was very adequate. In what way do you postpone a pencil? I have sometimes drafted Amendments to Finance Bills, but as my handwriting is so bad, I have always
used a typewriter. I think the Chancellor of the Exchequer will in due course, in his next Budget—which I presume will be introduced immediately after the Recess—have an opportunity of examining this Schedule with greater care. His predecessor who invented the Purchase Tax did not know what it meant and took three months to prepare the Bill. That Bill was abandoned and this Bill was introduced, having been drafted in a much greater hurry than the right hon. Gentleman indulged in when instructing his right hon. Friend and giving him briefs. If the briefs had not been better drawn there would not have been so successful a combination. I would seriously ask my right hon. Friend to give some reconsideration to this tax on what I have described as tools of trade. To a very large extent these things will be bought by people who will bear a tax which will be an increase in their business expenses. That will diminish their liability to Excess Profits Tax, and therefore he will only go through a process of transferring items from one side of the ledger to the other without getting any extra revenue. However, as it is useless to press the matter at this moment I beg to ask leave to withdraw the Amendment.
Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

On a point of Order, may I ask whether it is intended, on the next Amendment on the Order Paper, to have a discussion covering newspapers, periodicals and books altogether? Would it not be better, as different arguments will be adduced, to have a separate discussion?

I have said several times before, with regard to following Amendments, that hon. Members must wait and see. It is quite obvious that the Amendment to leave out lines 38 to 53 is an Amendment to leave out a whole item, and is one that has a number of particular items linked to it, which can be discussed separately or all together. I cannot rule it out of Order.

I beg to move, That the Chairman do report Progress, and ask leave to sit again. Am I in order in asking how far it is intended that we should go to-night? We are now about to enter into a discussion
which will be protracted unless the Chancellor is generous. If the Chancellor makes a statement, and it is unsatisfactory, will he insist upon a Division to-night or will he allow the Committee further to consider the statement? A great deal of progress has been made with the Bill this evening, and if we are to have a controversy about this tax, it ought not to be at this hour.

When the hon. Gentleman opposite has moved his Amendment, I propose to make a short statement which may perhaps relieve the difficulties and anxieties. We can then see how the statement goes. I do not think that the sitting ought to be protracted.
I beg to ask leave to withdraw the Motion.
Motion, by leave, withdrawn.

I beg to move, in page 44, column 2, to leave out lines 38 to 53.
In view of the hint which the Chancellor has thrown out I will not deal with this Amendment at great length, but I think it is necessary to put on record one or two facts about it. First of all, a tax of this character, especially at this time, would be a very great disaster to an industry which has already suffered great injury. It will in no way assist export trade of this country because this trade is not one that does any exporting. In addition to difficulties of the moment the industry is suffering from a paper shortage, and with the increase in the cost of inks, etc., there has been a great falling off of trade. The result has been that the balance of work now being produced by the printing industry has to bear the whole of the overhead costs. Printing is now costing more than it reasonably should cost. If you put a tax on the wholesale selling price, then you will tax it on the industry's inflated difficulties.
Then there is the difficulty of distinguishing between the various classes put down in column 2. I have been associated with the industry for many years, but I would not like to distinguish between a pamphlet, a leaflet, a book, a magazine and so on. Where one starts and the other ends it is almost impossible
to say. There is one other factor, too, which ought to be borne in mind. The printing industry has been described as the "art preservative of all arts." I think it can safely be said that it is an industry that is indispensable to all other industries, for no industry can flourish unless it has the service of the printing industry. To tax print in general would be a disservice to industry. When we come to periodicals and books, there are one or two points that I should like to mention. What do we mean by "periodicals and books"? Can anyone describe the difference? Do you mean that a book has a stiff cover, or that if it has a paper cover, it is a magazine? If you consider the case of Penguins, you will find some difficulty in coming to an understanding without a clear definition. Those interested in education are anxious that books should be free of tax. We want all literature free of tax. We have the wireless, but sometimes we are glad to get away from it. In these days of rumours when we hear of "silent columns" and are told "You must not talk" we should remember that it is not silence or talk which defeats rumours but statements in print, in papers that can be trusted. There are papers that you can trust. [HON. MEMBERS: "Name."] I should expect the ordinary advertising rates if I mentioned names. You can do more to stop rumours by having announcements that people can trust than by all the talk on the wireless telling you, "Do not be worried," or "There is nothing to be worried about." Even the B.B.C. believes in the immense value of the printed word because, if there is a talk of special value, they take particular care to reprint it in the "Listener" so that it shall be recorded for all time.
I ask that newspapers shall not be taxed, and I ask it not purely on the question of finance. The only country in the Empire that has a Purchase Tax is Canada, and they do not tax newspapers. There are several factors of importance about that. The main question is that of retaining a free Press. There is a danger of killing that if you put a tax on newspapers. Our newspapers are as good as any in the world, not only from the point of view of print but on account of the balanced way in which they present their opinions—in spite of the fact that many might be more balanced than they are. In the main, we have a Press which serves
the country fairly and decently. Some of the best papers are living on their resources. If you put on this tax, a paper must either increase its price to the purchaser, or reduce the commission to the retail newsagent, or pay the tax itself. If they pass it on to the customer, there is a risk of a shortage of purchases and of the trade going down. On the other hand, the purchaser will be making a present to the management of something in addition to the amount of the tax, and that will not be fair. It will not be fair to make the retailer pay it. The danger is that there are some groups of papers which would pay the tax themselves and not pass it on, whereas their competitors would be compelled to increase their price and in that way put themselves out of business, or possibly they would put themselves out of business by not increasing the price, and then not being able to carry on.
We should be faced with the position that the splendid local newspapers in the provincial towns, the wonderful newspapers in Manchester, Liverpool, Sheffield and Bristol—let every hon. Member think of the newspaper in his own town—would be in danger. I ask every hon. Member whether he would not prefer his own little local newspaper, with its intimate expressions of opinion, to a huge octopus Press printed in the locality, but spoonfed with news sent from London. There are many other things that could be said, but in view of what the Chancellor has said, I ask that, on the ground of the necessity of keeping literature as reasonably priced as possible, but above all, on the ground of keeping our small Press as free as possible and keeping out of the domination of a Press run either purely for money-making or to satisfy the whim and ambition of an individual, printing should be set free from the danger of this tax.

I think it will be convenient for me to intervene at this stage and give my views on the general claim which is being advanced for the exemption of newspapers, books and other printed matter from the operation of the Purchase Tax. There are also various Amendments on the Order Paper which propose exemptions for particular classes of books or periodicals. In the brief statement that I now propose to make, I
shall deal with the wider question, which I recognise involves other considerations than those that we have been discussing this afternoon and this evening with regard to other items in the Schedule. As regards the taxation of newspapers, the industry have put their case to me, by way of representation and reasoned argument through deputations from all sections of the newspaper industry. They have particularly put to me in an objective manner the present general financial position of each section, and the possible consequences of this tax on the circulation of newspapers, and even the prospects of continuance in some cases. I need hardly say to the Committee that I have examined most carefully these representations in the spirit in which they were submitted to me.
As far as books are concerned, at an early stage I received a representative deputation, and since then more than one eminent publisher has been good enough to provide me with facts and figures comparable to those in the case of newspapers, to which I have just referred. The Committee is familiar with what has happened since then. I must say that I feel that a great deal of the sound and fury of the campaign has been unjustifiable, but in spite of the human reactions to certain aspects of it—and to which even the Chancellor of the Exchequer may be entitled—I have endeavoured to sift the wheat from the chaff, and to give careful attention and impartial consideration to all the matters that have been put to me in this case.
I should like to deal with only one aspect of the suggestion that this is a tax on culture, a tax on knowledge and a direct blow at those very things of the mind and spirit for which we are now fighting. I must confess that I feel myself in some difficulty here. It is obvious in the first place that the more I accept the advice of some of my hon. Friends, and certain advisers outside, the more difficult I shall be making it for the people of this country who spend their money on books, periodicals, and to a lesser degree newspapers. Already I believe many taxpayers must find it virtually impossible to maintain expenditure of this kind at anything like its pre-war level. Yet I do not conceive that Parliament would wish any Chancellor to
refrain for this reason from such measures of taxation, however severe, as he might think for the prosecution of the war.
The effect, of course, of severe taxation would be felt by the newspaper trade, and by the book trade, just as it is being felt by others; and, if the time comes when we have to choose between money for books, and money for such despised articles as boots, or between magazines and milk, then we shall have to choose boots and milk, and, with all due respect to some of my hon. Friends, that choice will be right. In the case of newspapers, as I have said, I have had the benefit of consultation with all sections of the industry, and I have paid particular attention to some of the results which, as I have said, might follow from the application of this tax. Either the price of the ordinary penny newspaper would need to be increased to 1½d. or the newspapers would need to absorb the cost with other increases of costs arising from the war and in an endeavour to recoup themselves alter to such extent as they could the services which they provide to the public.
It has also been suggested to me that some papers would be unable to continue. At any rate the figures which have been placed before me show there might well be, in certain events, a substantial decrease in circulation of newspapers. I certainly do not think that in this time of war it would be in the national interest that there should be either a decrease in the circulation of newspapers or a diminution of the service which they provide for the public. Not only a free Press, but a widely distributed Press is, I recognise, a vital factor, particularly to-day in the dissemination of information and in the maintenance of public morale. This, of course, would not affect so considerably, I think, the circulation of the principal national newspapers, but I have particularly in mind he many local and provincial newspapers which serve our interests so well. They would suffer and with them the public which they serve.
I have of course to balance these considerations against the loss of revenue which would be involved, but, on the whole, though I cannot accept the contention that the printed word should necessarily be immune from taxation I have reached the conclusion—and in this I
may say I have been helped by the co-operation which the Committee has extended to me in other respects—that the revenue, although important, does not justify me, having regard to the important considerations I have mentioned, in maintaining the tax on newspapers in present circumstances.
I now turn to the claim for the exemption of books, and I will try in this instance, too, to give the case as I see it without the ornamental additions. There are many factors which will necessarily discourage the sale and purchase of books in this country during the war. I have already alluded to some of them, such as the increasing burden of taxation upon the incomes and spending power of the people. There are also, I recognise, strong points in the economic case which can be made for the exemption of books. There is the undoubted fact that, apart from any action which I may take, difficulties may well increase as the war goes on, thus making it more difficult for the publishing business to continue its work and for the people to purchase new books. Above all—and this is the matter to which I attach the greatest importance in the considerations I have had to weigh—there is the undoubted importance to this country of the export trade in books, an importance which springs both from the financial results of that trade and from the necessity of the continued spread of British thoughts and writings throughout the world. The success or failure of that trade is related particularly closely to the success or failure of the home trade, because, as some of my hon. Friends know, this is one of the trades where there is a very big disparity between the price at which goods are sold at home and the price at which they are sold abroad. In other words, for a book to be a successful export, it must also provide a lucrative investment at home.
Finally, I do not under-estimate the importance to be attached to the publication of valuable but unremunerative books, which is only justified and made possible by the sale of less original, but more fashionable works. I can appreciate arguments of this kind, and, while there is much to be said to the contrary, in view of the considerations to which I have referred, which do not apply to other articles in the Schedule, I think
that, on the whole, I should agree that books, as well as newspapers, should be exempt from the tax—at least, for the present. This decision must extend to printed music and printed leaflets and pamphlets, including, I may say, "The Book Crisis," if further copies should be required, and such others items as trade catalogues, trade lists, trade posters, and other trade advertising materials, as revenue from these would be comparatively small and not worth maintaining in themselves alone.
As it has been represented to me that the Purchase Tax will involve traders in keeping special accounts and that in those circumstances it is little short of something evil to charge a tax on account books, or even on plain books whether ruled or not, I propose to extend the exemption in that direction too. Diaries, I think, should continue to be the subject of taxation; a great book lover included these among the books that are no books. I shall therefore agree to the deletion from the Schedule of the paragraph concerned.
Amendment agreed to.

I beg to move, in page 45, line 7, column 3, after "omnibuses," to insert "trolley vehicles."
I cannot conceive that the Chancellor intended that trolley buses should be taxed. I move this Amendment in order to enable him to make a statement, and I think I shall find that his intention was that they should not be taxed.

My hon. Friend is quite right in thinking that my right hon. Friend did not wish to exclude trolley vehicles from column 3. I can assure my hon. Friend that they are regarded as being covered by the exemptions in column 3.
Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

I beg to move, in page 45, line 10, column 3, after "fire-engines," to insert: vehicles used for or in connection with the extinction of fires or the protection of life or property in case of fire. I think the inclusion of fire-engines is an admission of their usefulness to the community, but they are only of use if they are supplemented by the accessories, that is to say other vehicles which are necessary, and in the opinion of those who have asked me to put down this Amendment those other vehicles should be included in column 3.

As a matter of fact fire-engines ought not to be here at all. The fact that they are inserted here makes it look as though they were road vehicles for the conveyance of passengers, but they are not that at all. We shall in due course move to take out the words "fire-engines" and that will meet my hon. Friend's point.
I beg to ask leave to withdraw the Amendment.
Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.
Schedule, as amended, agreed to.
Remaining Schedules agreed to.
Bill reported with Amendments; as amended, to be considered upon Thursday, and to be printed. [No. 81]
